posts.title: Birthday Wishes for NYPL Lions Patience and Fortitude
posts.text: On Monday, May 11, The New York Public Library celebrated the birthday of our beloved lions.

posts.title: #LoveReading: Valentines for Book Lovers
posts.text: How do we #LoveReading? Let us count the ways.

posts.title: Quiz: How Well Do You Know Patience and Fortitude?
posts.text: Patience and Fortitude are the beloved lions located outside of our 42nd Street location. These timeless lions have been guarding the Library for over 100 years—but how well do you really know them? Our fact-filled quiz will help you find out!

posts.title: Listen: Neil Gaiman Reads "A Christmas Carol"
posts.text: We're celebrating the publication anniversary of the Dickens' classic with this special reading by Neil Gaiman from 2013.

posts.title: Election Day 2019: Get Informed and Vote
posts.text: Get out and vote.

posts.title: Introducing the 2019 Library Lions Honorees
posts.text: This year the Library is pleased to announce the 2019 Library Lions: Elizabeth Alexander, Philip Glass, Jamaica Kincaid, Jill Lepore, and Frederick Wiseman.

posts.title: Banned Books Week 2019
posts.text: Banned Books Week is an annual event promoting the importance of the freedom to read, and highlighting attempts to censor books in schools and libraries.

posts.title: Books and Ink: The Literary Tattoos of NYPL Staff
posts.text: Tattooing has been around for thousands of years, and it's no surprise that books and literature often serve as tattoo inspiration.

posts.title: Avengers Assemble for Book Recommendations
posts.text: To honor one of the biggest movie franchises of our time, we started wondering: What should the Avengers read?

posts.title: #LiteraryMarchMadness 2019: Heroes and Villains Edition
posts.text: Welcome to NYPL's Sixth Annual Literary March Madness (#LiteraryMarchMadness)! This is a bracket-style tournament like the NCAA March Madness basketball tournament, but with a bookish twist: our competition pits popular heroes and villains against each other and the winner is decided by you!

posts.title: The Sixth Annual #LibraryShelfie Day
posts.text: Every year on the fourth Wednesday of January, libraries and book lovers across social media put a bookish spin on a selfie by taking photos with bookshelves and using the perfect hashtag—#LibraryShelfie!

posts.title: Reading the 2019 Awards Season: Oscars Edition
posts.text: The nominees for the 2019 Academy Awards have been announced. While the films are being celebrated, we couldn't help but notice something: books played major roles in many of the contenders for the 91st Oscars.

posts.title: A Morning with the 2018 National Book Awards Finalists
posts.text: On the morning of the National Book Awards, we sat down with some of the finalists to ask them questions about books they have read a million times, which NYPL lion they identify with the most, and more.

posts.title: One for the Books: NYPL Kicks Off New Chapter in Baseball’s Greatest Rivalry with a Wager against Boston Public Library
posts.text: The New York Public Library and Boston Public Library have teamed up to have some fun around the American League Division Series between longtime, bitter rivals The New York Yankees and Boston Red Sox.

posts.title: Inside Poetry Series: What Is The Anatomy of a Poem?
posts.text: There are about as many parts to a poem as the imagination can hold.

posts.title: For the Young at Heart: Adult Books on Children's Literature
posts.text: As adults, nostalgia may lead us to revisit and reconsider the stories of our youth, so we've assembled this list of adult books that turn a critical eye toward children's favorites.

posts.title: NYPL Events: What's Happening 9/4–9/18
posts.text: With 92 locations across New York City, there's a lot going on! We're highlighting some of our events here, including author talks, free classes, community art shows, performances, concerts, and exhibitions.

posts.title: The Library Welcomes Angela Yee as an NYPL Ambassador
posts.text: The New York Public Library is pleased to announce that nationally-syndicated radio personality, lifelong New Yorker, and die-hard library enthusiast Angela Yee is now an NYPL Ambassador.

posts.title: Announcing Our 2018 Summer Reading Essay Contest Winners
posts.text: On August 16, The New York Public Library will be honoring three young readers who participated in our Summer Reading Challenge. For this year's challenge, patrons between ages 6-18 were asked to write an essay about a favorite book and how it impacted them.

posts.title: Quiz: Are You Patience or Fortitude?
posts.text: Patience and Fortitude, the lions that stand proudly in front of the Library's 42nd Street location, have captured the imagination and affection of New Yorkers since 1911. But which lion do you identify more with: Patience or Fortitude?

posts.title: Everything You Need to Celebrate National Book Lovers Day
posts.text: At the New York Public Library, it's no surprise that National Book Lovers Day is one of our favorite days. That's why we're gathering everything a bibliophile needs to celebrate—from literary tweets to tools to access books on-the-go, and great photos of fellow readers.

posts.title: True Crime Books for True Fans of the Genre
posts.text: Now that you've read many of the most well-known works of true crime, you may be looking not just for your next read, but also for even more unusual or sophisticated examples of the genre.

posts.title: Introducing the 2018 Library Lions Honorees
posts.text: Each year The New York Public Library honors several distinguished individuals for outstanding achievements in their respective fields of arts, culture, letters and scholarship by naming them Library Lions. In 2018, the Library will honor Ron Chernow, Francis Ford Coppola, Jessye Norman, Claudia Rankine, and Elizabeth Strout.

posts.title: Can You Guess the Book Titles from These Emojis?
posts.text: In honor of our love of books and emojis, we're putting you to the test: can you guess the book titles from the emojis?

posts.title: #RainbowReading: NYC Libraries March at Pride 2018
posts.text: On June 24, The New York Public Library joined Queens Public Library and Brooklyn Public Library at the 2018 New York City Pride March. See photos of library staff members celebrating Pride.

posts.title: Where to Start with Octavia Butler
posts.text: Octavia Butler was a groundbreaking writer in American letters. The first science fiction writer to ever receive the MacArthur Fellowship, Butler transcended the conventions of her chosen genre.

posts.title: Inside Poetry Series: How Should I Read Poems Out Loud?
posts.text: Is there a "right" way to read poetry aloud? No. But 4 tips from a former Poet Laureate can certainly help.

posts.title: Inside Poetry Series: What Are the Different Types of Poetry?
posts.text: Narrative or lyric? Epistle or sonnet? Our multi-part series continues with the myriad ways to classify and categorize poems.

posts.title: Where to Start with Walt Whitman
posts.text: Primarily known today as a poet, Whitman wrote across genres, including poetry, fiction, and nonfiction. If you're developing an interest in his writing, read on for a brief guide to getting started with Walt Whitman's work.

posts.title: Inside Poetry Series: Where Do I Find Poems?
posts.text: If you’re interested in poetry but wondering where poems might be hiding, we'll help you identify books to read and compilations to peruse.

posts.title: Inside Poetry Series: What Is Poetry, Anyway?
posts.text: If you're thinking of returning to poetry now, you may have tons of questions: what really constitutes poetry? How do you find poems that suit your tastes? How do you find cool new poets or figure out which classics to read? We're here to help!

posts.title: Announcing the 2018 Young Lions Fiction Award Finalists
posts.text: We're pleased to announce the finalists for the eighteenth annual Young Lions Fiction Award, honoring the works of five talented young authors.

posts.title: #LiteraryMarchMadness 2018: Which Character Will Be the Champion?
posts.text: Welcome to our Fifth Annual Literary March Madness (#LiteraryMarchMadness)! This is a bracket-style tournament like the NCAA March Madness basketball tournament, but with a bookish twist: our competition pits popular literary characters against each other and the winner is decided by you!

posts.title: Reading Across America: A Book for Every State (and D.C. Too)
posts.text: We put together a list of 51 books, one for each state in the United States and the District of Columbia. In each book, the action primarily takes place in the state it was chosen for, and we've blended each state's classics with some outside-the-box choices.

posts.title: Where to Start with Alice Walker
posts.text: February 9 marks the birthday of Alice Walker, prolific American novelist, short story writer, poet and activist.

posts.title: Celebrating Books with #LibraryShelfie Day
posts.text: On the fourth Wednesday of January each year, libraries and readers across social media share selfies with bookshelves and tag them #LibraryShelfie! Here are some of our favorite 2018 shelfies!

posts.title: Anything Is Paw-sible with These Literary Pups
posts.text: Don't let the Library's lion mascot fool you; we have a lot of love for literary dogs. Our four-legged friends often find themselves at the heart of a great book, or tagging along for the adventure as a faithful human companion.

posts.title: NYPL Events: What's Happening 01/08-01/22
posts.text: Welcome to our bi-weekly update on events happening during the next two weeks at The New York Public Library. With 92 locations across New York City, a lot is happening at the Library. We're highlighting some of our events here, including author talks, free classes, community art shows, performances, concerts, and exhibitions.

posts.title: Libraries Extend Beyond Walls
posts.text: At The New York Public Library, we believe that libraries extend beyond walls. Today we discuss opportunities available at the Library to those who need them most.

posts.title: We Preserve Knowledge
posts.text: At The New York Public Library, we preserve knowledge. Today we discuss remarkable additions to our research collections and their preservation online to ensure their continued prominence and relevance for future generations.

posts.title: Libraries Build Communities
posts.text: This post is part of a series where we review what has happened at The New York Public Library in 2017. Today we discuss how we meet the growing and ever-changing need for the Library's services.

posts.title: We Believe in Literacy for All
posts.text: This post is part of a series where we review what has happened at The New York Public Library in 2017. Today we discuss the steps we've taken to increase literacy: getting more people reading more and fine forgiveness.

posts.title: Meet the 2017 Library Lions Honorees
posts.text: Each year The New York Public Library honors several distinguished individuals for outstanding achievements in their respective fields of arts, culture, letters and scholarship by naming them Library Lions. On November 6, the Library will honor Colson Whitehead, Michael Chabon, Carla Hayden, Robert Wilson, and Tom Brokaw as 2017 Library Lions.
